Aux:TextAnnotations.Aux:document_text: Thirty years after Zaha Hadid’s premiated but sadly unbuilt entry to the 1983 competition for The Peak Leisure Club in Hong Kong immediately made her a contender for inclusion in the pantheon of great 20th-century architects, she finally built her first permanent work of architecture in that city. Completed in the middle of 2013, Innovation Tower (or, more precisely, the Jockey Club Innovation Tower: the Hong Kong Jockey Club donated a quarter-billion Hong Kong dollars toward its construction and in return gained naming rights) is home to the School of Design of PolyU, the Hong Kong Polytechnic University. The School of Design was founded in the 1960s, but the origins of PolyU lie in the Government Trade School, founded just before World War II as the first publicly funded tertiary technical institution in Hong Kong. Over the years, the campus has filled up with an orthogonal array of mostly rectilinear buildings, leaving vacant only the irregular lot at the northwest corner that is now the site of Innovation Tower: ‘a beacon structure symbolising and driving the development of Hong Kong as a design hub in Asia’, according to the brief of the competition that Hadid won in 2007. Entailing three years of design development and three years of construction, the resulting building accommodates 1,800 people in a net floor area of 15,000 m2, which includes a lecture hall, classrooms, design studios, workshops, exhibition spaces, shops, a cafeteria and a communal lounge
